

when a new user wants to access to the cluster: 
 1. new user creates his own key and generates his won certificate signing request. 
    
    $ openssl genrsa -out smith.key 2048
    $ openssl req -new -key smith.key -subj "/CN=smith" -out smith.csr

 ## kubernetes has a built-in certificate api that can sign, approve and manage certificates. 

#  When administrator recieves a certificate signing request he creates a kubernetes api object called 
   CertificateSigningRequest. 

# Once the object is created requests can be reviewed and approved using kubectl commands. 


These are the steps:
--------------------
  1. user creates and send his certificate signing request to the admin. 
  2. admin creates the signing request object file -- 
apiVersion: certificates.k8s.io/v1beta1
kind: CertificateSigningRequest
metadata:
  name: smith
spec:
  groups:
  - system:authenticated
  request: 
  usages:
  - server auth
  - digintal signature
  - key encipherment


## 
admin coverts the user's csr file into base64 and paste that in the request field.  
##
command to convert: 
  $ cat smith.csr | base64



# commands to view details:
  $ kubectl get csr 
  $ kubectl get csr <csr name>
  $ kubectl certificate approve smith
    or to deny 
  $ kubectl certificate deny smith 

# kuberentes signs the certificate with CA key pair and generates a certificate for the user. 
# This certificate then can be extracted and shared with the user. 

# view the certificate in a yaml format. 

  $ kubectl get csr smith -o yaml 

generated certificate is part of the output. But is in a base64 encoded format. To decode it 
  $ echo "kdfhalsdf...." | base64 --decode > smith.cert
